title.justification: This is the title as mentioned in the arXiv listing.

extractions.description: This paper proposes Invariant Causal Set Covering Machines (ICSCM), an extension of the classical Set Covering Machine algorithm, to avoid spurious associations and identify causal parents in polynomial time. Theoretical foundations and an empirical study are presented to validate the approach.

type.justification: The paper presents a new algorithm with theoretical validation and initial empirical results demonstrating its correctness and efficiency.
type.quote: We demonstrate both theoretically and empirically that our method can identify the causal parents of a variable of interest in polynomial time.

name.justification: The paper focuses on rule-based models and algorithms for learning causal relationships, which falls under the domain of Machine Learning.
name.quote: In some fields of application of machine learning, the use of learned models goes well beyond prediction.

name.justification: The paper builds on invariant causal prediction literature to propose the new algorithm ICSCM.
name.quote: Our work builds on previous advances in invariant causal prediction (Peters et al., 2016; Heinze-Deml et al., 2018; BÃ¼hlmann, 2020)

name.justification: The paper extends the classical Set Covering Machine which is a type of rule-based learning algorithm.
name.quote: We propose Invariant Causal Set Covering Machines (ICSCM), an extension of the Set Covering Machine algorithm (Marchand & Shawe-Taylor, 2002).

name.justification: The paper explicitly proposes and discusses the Invariant Causal Set Covering Machines (ICSCM) model.
name.quote: We propose Invariant Causal Set Covering Machines (ICSCM).

is_contributed.justification: The ICSCM model is introduced by this paper itself.
is_contributed.quote: We propose Invariant Causal Set Covering Machines (ICSCM).

is_executed.justification: The paper includes an empirical study where the ICSCM is executed on simulated data.
is_executed.quote: We conduct a brief empirical study with simulated data to verify the correctness of the theory and the efficiency of the algorithm (Section 4).

is_compared.justification: The paper compares ICSCM with Set Covering Machine (SCM), decision trees (DT), and invariant causal prediction (ICP).
is_compared.quote: The baselines that we consider are Set Covering Machines (SCM; Marchand & Shawe-Taylor (2002)), decision trees (DT; Breiman et al. (1984)), and non-linear ICP (ICP; Heinze-Deml et al. (2018)).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Set Covering Machine algorithm, which ICSCM extends, is detailed in this referenced paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We propose Invariant Causal Set Covering Machines (ICSCM), an extension of the Set Covering Machine algorithm (Marchand & Shawe-Taylor, 2002).

name.justification: The authors use simulated data from a discrete Bayesian network to verify the correctness of their theory.
name.quote: We now report a brief empirical study. These experiments are by no means extensive, but they support the validity of the proposed algorithm and theory. Simulated Data: We parametrize a discrete Bayesian network that satisfies the assumptions at Section 2.1.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Simulated data sets do not have a referenced paper title.

name.justification: Scikit-learn is mentioned as one of the libraries used for implementing baseline methods in the paper.
name.quote: We used the implementation available in Scikit-Learn (version 1.2.2; Pedregosa et al. (2011)) and considered the following hyperparameter values.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Scikit-learn's implementation and usage refer to this paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We used the implementation available in Scikit-Learn (version 1.2.2; Pedregosa et al. (2011)).
